titleStmt.title: Tamiḻneṟi Viḷakkam 16.
Experimenting with formatting for the final edition.

div.p: [The friend] questioning [the hero], [the hero] letting out [the secret]; [the hero's friend] reproaching [the hero], [the hero] refuting [that reproach], [the friend’s] suffering; [when asked by the friend], “Where?”, [the hero] saying, “In such a place”; [the friend] seeing the woman, [the friend] classifying [her as] agreeable, [the friend] speaking to the hero, [the hero] making it clear that he cannot bear, and sending [her] off to the old ones (i.e. her family) - these are 'the union [by means of] his friend'.
The quoted [cūttiram] intends to make known the way in which the union [by means of] his friend occurs.

pāṅkaṉ ṟalaimakaṟkuṟṟa viṉātalun talaimakaṉ iṉṉateṉṟalum pāṅkaṉ kaḻaṟalun talaimakaṉ kaḻaṟṟetir maṟuttalum pāṅkaṉōtalum evviṭattevvuru veṉṟalun talaimakaṉ iṉṉa viṭattiṉṉa vuru veṉṟalum pāṅkaṉ avviṭattavvuruk kāṇṭalun talaimakaṉaip perumai kūṟalum peyarntu vantu talaimakaṟkuraittalun talaimakaṉ ṟalaimakaḷaik kaṇṭaṇaitalum uṟaviṉ āṟṟāṉ kūṟalum viṭuttalum pāṅkaṟ kūṭṭam ām eṉṟa vāṟu.

His friend questioning the hero about what has happened [to him]; the hero saying "it is so"; the hero's friend reproaching [the hero]; [the hero] refuting [his friend's] reproach; his friend's suffering; [his friend] saying, "In what place and in what way?"; [the hero] saying, "In such a place and in such a way";What seems to be one situation in the cūttiram - yāṇṭeṉa viṉṉuḻi yeṉṟal ('[when asked] "Where?" saying "In such a place."), I take to be treated as two here. The Tamil allows one to understand this as one, but as this commentary closely follows the IAC, I have chosen to mirror its construction and take these as distinct situations. his friend seeing [her] at that place; [his friend] speaking of [the hero's] greatness; [the friend] leaving and telling [the hero about the place]; the hero seeing the heroine and approaching [her]; [the hero] not being able to bear the experience and speaking; and sending [the heroine] off - [these] are the union [by means of] his friend.
The hero talks to his friend.
The hero's friend becomes able to say, "He (the hero) is wrong."
The hero's friend asks about the place [where the lovers met].
The hero tells [his friend] the location of the tryst.
[The hero's friend] talks about the hero's ability to bear [her beauty].
The hero's friend leaves [the trysting-spot], comes back and tells the hero [about it].
The hero goes to that place.
eṉpatu talaimakaṉ aṇaital uṟaviṉ āṟṟāṉ kūṟiyatu.
The hero talks about his inability to bear the experience of approaching [the heroine].

standOff.note: Cf. TP487i: paṅkoṭu taḻāalum
Cf. TP99i.9: niṟpavai niṉaii nikaḻpavai yuraippiṉuṅ | kūṟṟaṅ kāṭṭiya vāyil peṭpiṉum
Cf. IA3: āṅṅaṉam puṉarnta kiḻavōṉ ṟaṉvayiṟ | pāṅka ṉōriṟ kuṟitalaip peyartalum
Iḷampūraṉar and Nacciṉārkkiṉiyar both understand these lines in TP99i to refer to the friend's reproach. This is the only mention in the TP concerning this situation.

The IA parallel simply mentions the existence of a meeting in which the hero's friend plays some sort of role, but there is no elaboration on the figure. The first instance of any expansion of teh situation come in Nakkīraṉār's commentary. As before, I am quite certain that it was the source for this cūttiram, but as the commentary shows closer similarities to the wording found in the IAC, I have provided it there.

AV136 gives a list of situations that one could try and map onto that provided here, but the similarities are not great. Where one finds strong similarities are in AV137, the exposition on the situations listed in 136. These are parallels to the TNVC and both seem to follow the IAC closely in both content and phrasing.
Cf. IAC3, p. 49: 'eṉṉai kollō emperumāṟku iṟṟai vēṟupāṭṭu vāṭṭam' eṉṉum
Cf. IAC3, p. 49: kaṭaippiṭittu viṉaviya pāṅkaṟku, 'nerunal ivvakaiyār oruvaraik kaṇṭēṟku eṉ uḷḷam puḷḷattu vaḻi veḷḷampōl ōṭi, ivvakaittu āyiṟṟu' eṉṟu collum;
Cf. IAC3, p. 50: ivvāṟu collakkēṭṭa pāṅkaṉ kaḻaṟum
Cf. IAC3, p. 50: ivvāṟu pāṅkaṉ kaḻaṟat, talaimakaṉ āṟṟāṉāyc collum corṟkaḷ kaḻaṟṟetirmaṟai eṉpatu
Cf. IAC3, p. 51: ivvāṟu talaimakaṉ taṉatu āṟṟāmaiyiṉ kaḻaṟṟetir maṟuttu uraippak kēṭṭa pāṅkaṉ... eṉa kavaṉṟāṉ
Cf. IAC3, p. 52: 'evviṭattu? ettaṉmaittu? niṉṟār kāṇapaṭṭa uru' eṉṉum.
Cf. IAC3, p. 52: 'ivviṭattu ittaṉmaittu eṉṟār kāṇapaṭṭa uru' eṉṉum.
Cf. IAC3, p. 53: kaṇṭu, 'ivviṭamē avaṉāṟ kāṇappaṭṭa iṭamum, ivvuruvē avaṉāṟ kāṇappaṭṭa uruvum' eṉat tuṇiyum.
Cf. IAC3, p. 54: '...iṟantupaṭātu eṉkāṟum vanta iruntuṇaip peruntakkāṉai yāṉ periyatōr iṭaṉaṉṟik kaḻaṟiṉēṉ' eṉa niṉaikkum.
Cf. IAC3, p. 54: āṟṟiyuḷaṉāyt talaimakaṉaic ceṉṟeyti, 'yāṉ kaṇṭa iṭam mētakkatē kāṇ' eṉṉum;
Cf. IAC3, p. 56: aṭaiyavē maṟaivatu kāṇātu, mātupaṭunōkki naṉ maṇikkāntaṇ melviralāṟ pōtupurai neṭuṅkaṇ putaittāḷ.
Cf. IAC3, p. 55: āṟṟāmai eṉpatu piṟitu evvuṇarvum iṉṟi avvaṟṟāmai tāṉē āvatu. avvāṟṟāmai āṟṟuvatu oṉṟaṉaip paṟṟum. āṟṟuvatu piṟitu iṉmaiyiṉ orucoṟ collum.
Cf. AV137.1-2:... pāṅkaṉ | ṟalaivaṉai yuṟṟatu viṉātalum
Cf. AV137.2-3:... talaivaṉ | uṟṟa tuṟaittalum
Cf. AV137.3-4:... pāṅkaṉ | kaḻaṟalum
Cf. AV137.4-5:... kiḻavōṉ kaḻaṟetir maṟuttalum |
Cf. AV137.6-7:... pāṅkaṉ | taṉmaṉat taḻuṅkalum
Cf. AV137.8: evviṭat tevviyaṟ ṟeṉṟalum
Cf. AV137.8-9: avaṉaḵ | tivviṭat tivviyaṟ ṟeṉṟalum
Cf. AV137.11: iṟaiviyai kāṇṭalum
Cf. AV137.12: talaiviyai viyattalum
Cf. AV137.14: talaivaṉ cēṟalum talaiviyai kāṇṭalum
Cf. AV137.15-16: talaiviyaip | pāṅkiyoṭu varukeṉap pakartal

The parallels here are sometimes not exact. The IAC introduces situations by explaining them and doesn't normally provide a specific term for them, whearas the TNV commentary does. In some of cases, the TNV commentator uses the wording from the IAC. I have provided the most pertinent part of the corresponding passage.
This final situation is not found in the IAC, but only in the AV.
Cf. PK23.2-4 (IAC3, p.49):...koḻuntamiḻiṉ | oṇturai mēluḷḷa mōṭiya tōvaṉṟi yuṟṟatuṇṭō | taṇturai vācintai vāṭiṭa eṉṉai taḷarkiṉṟatē ||
Cf. KT129.5-6 (IAC3, p.50): katuppayal viḷaṅkuñ ciṟunutal | putukkōḷ yāṉaiyiṟ piṇittaṟṟā lemmē ||

Cf. PK25 (IAC3, p.49): aḷaiyā raraviṉ kuruḷai yaṇaṅka aṟivaḻintu | tuḷaiyār neṭuṅkaik kaḷiṟu neṭuṅkit tuyarvatupōl | vaḷaiyār muḷaiyeyiṟ ṟarmaṉṉaṉ māṟaṉvaṇ kūṭalaṉṉa | iḷaiyā roruva raṇaṅkanain tāmmey iḷaikkiṉṟatē ||

This poem is also quoted in the commentary to IA3 to exemplify the situation where the hero reveals to his friend that he is pining after the heroine. Other poems which employ the same image of something (which represents the heroine) entrancing an elephant (the hero) are provided as parallels.
Cf. IAC3, p.50:..."appeṟṟiyāya nī, iṉṉatōr iṭattu iṉṉatōr uruvukaṇṭu, 'eṉ uruvu aḻiyap pōnteṉ' eṉṟal takkiṉru eṉṉum.
Though there are poems quoted in IAC3 for this situation, this seems to be a case where the TNVC poem more closely resemebles the prose summary of these poems.
Cf. AN130, (IAC3, p.51): amma vāḻi kōḷir muṉṉiṉṟu | kaṇṭaṉi rāyiṟ kaḻaṟaliṟ maṉṉō ... uṇkaṇ | mātar vāṇmuka mataiiya nōkkē ||
Cf. PK30.3-4, (IAC3, p.51): vaṇṭār kuḻaṉmaṭa maṅkai matarvaimeṉ ṉōkkameṉpōṟ | kaṇṭā ruḷarē luraiyār piṟaviṉṉa kaṭṭuraiyē ||
Cf. PK31.3-4, (IAC3, p.51): paṇkoṇṭa collam maṭantai mukattuppaim pūṅkuvaḷaik | kaṇkaṇṭa piṉṉai yuraiyī ruraittavik kaṭṭuraiyē ||
Just the main sentence of AN130 is quoted. It is a long poem and this is the relevant section.
Cf. PK32.3-4, (IAC3, p.52):... niṟaiyu maṟivuṅ kalaṅki nilaitaḷarum | eṉṟāl teruṭṭaval vāriṉi yāriv virunilattē ||
Cf. PK34.3-4, (IAC3, p.52):...urainiṉ | oṇṭā rakalam melivitta mātar uraiviṭamē ||
The TNVC poem does not make explicit the question of where the two lovers met. It does, however, mirror the concern of the hero's friend.

Cf. PK35 (IAC3, p.52): aṭivaṇṇan tāmarai āṭara valkul varattamaṅkai | koṭivaṇṇam nuṇṇiṭai kovvaicev vāykoṅkaikōṅ karumpiṉ | paṭivaṇṇañ ceṅkōṟ parāṅkucaṉ kollip paṉivaraiyāy | vaṭivaṇṇa vēṟkaṇṇi ṉāleṉṉai vāṭṭiya vāṇutaṟkē ||

Cf. PK36 (IAC3, p.52): tirumā mukantiṅkaḷ ceṅkayal uṇkaṇcem poṟcuṇaṅkēr | vārumā mulaimaṇic ceppiṇai vāṉavaṉ kāṉamuṉṉak | karumā neṭumatiṟ kōṭṭāṟ ṟaraṅkoṇṭa teṉṉaṉkaṉṉip | perumāṉ varōtayaṉ kolliyañ cāralppeṇ koṭikkē ||

Cf. PK37 (IAC3, p.53): kaṭittaṭam viṇṭ kamala mukaṅkama lattarumpē | poṭittaṭaṅ kāmulai pūlantait temmaṉṉar pūaḻiya | iṭittaṭaṅ kāvuru mēntiya kōṉkolli yīrmpoḻilvāy | vaṭittaṭaṅ kaṇmala rāleṉṉai vāṭṭiya vāṇutaṟkē ||

Cf. PK38 (IAC3, p.54): taṇtā talarkaṇṇi yaṇṇaltaṉ ṉuḷḷan taḷarvuceyt | vaṇṭār kuḻalava ḷēyivaḷ māṉīr maṇaṟṟimaṅkai | viṇṭār uṭaṟkuṉṟa mēṟi viḻikaḷ kaḻutuṟaṅkak | kaṇtāṉ potiyil ituvē avaṉcoṉṉa kārppuṉamē ||

Cf. PK39 (IAC3, p.54): ciṉamu maḻintu cerubiṭait tōṟṟatev vēntarkaḷpōyk | kaṉavumpaṭikaṭai yaṟceṟṟa vēntaṉ karuṅkuḻalār | maṉmum vaṭikkaṇṇun taṅkuman tārattu maṉṉaṉkaṉṉip | puṉamum ituvitu vēyavaṉ tāṉkaṇṭa pūṅkoṭiyē||
Cf. IAC3, p.54:'... iṟantupaṭātu eṉkārum vanta iruntuṇaip peruntakkaṉai yāṉ periyatōr iṭaṉaṉṟik kaḻaṟiṉēṉ' eṉa niṉaikkum.
Cf. PK41.4 (IAC3, p.54): ariya malarneṭuṅ kaṇkaṇṭu mālaṇṇal āṟṟiyatē ||
The TNVC poem has much more in common with the IAC prose preamble to these poems, though there is some similarity to the line proved from PK41.
Cf. PN21.5: katirnuḻai kallā marampayil kaṭimiḷai |

Cf. IAC3, p.55: iravō raṉṉa koḻuniḻal tāay | nilavō raṉṉa veṇmaṇa loḻuki | vaṇṭun tēṉum varikkaṭaip piracamuṅ | koṇṭu puṇarnaram peṉṟu muraṉṟu | viḻaivu viṭutta viḻumi yōraiyum | viḻaivu tōṟṟu nikkum paṇpiṟṟu ||
Cf. PK52.4 (IAC3, p.55): ērmaṉṉu kōtaiyaip pōliṉi tāyiṟṟiv vīrmpoḻilē ||
Cf. NA185.11: viṉaimāṇ pāvai yaṉṉōḷ |
Cf. IAC3, p.55: 'niṉṉai yāṉ ip poḻiluṟu teyvam eṉa aiyuṟuval, allai yāyiṉ vāytiṟavāy, āvi ceṉṟāl peyarppatu ariteṉrō'

Cf. PK45 (IAC3, p.56): mēviyoṉ ṉāraiveṇ māttuveṉ ṟāṉkaṉṉi vīḻtuṟaivāyt | tēviyeṉ ṟāniṉṉai yāṉiṉaik kiṉṟatu cēyaripāy | kāviveṉ ṟāyakaṇ ṇāyallai yēloṉṟu kaṭṭuraiyāy | āviceṉ ṟāṟpeyarp pariṉi yāriv vakaliṭattē ||

Cf. PK46 (IAC3, p.56): tiraiyuṟai vārpuṉaṟ cēvūrc cerumaṉṉar cīraḻitta | uraiyuṟai tīntamiḻ vēntaṉ ucitaṉāṇ pūmpotilyil | varaiyuṟai teyvameṉ ṟēṟkallai yēluṉṟaṉ vāytiṟavāy | viraiyuṟai kōtai uyircelliṉ yārpiṟar mīṭpavarē ||
